hero.title: Tension Gas Spring
hero.subtitle: Pull Gas Spring / Reverse Action Gas Spring - Professional Industrial Solutions

items.label: Product Name
items.value: Tension Gas Spring / Pull Gas Spring / Reverse Action Gas Spring

items.label: Free State
items.value: The piston rod is in the "retracted" position

items.label: Working Characteristic
items.value: Extends when pulled, automatically retracts when released

mainFunction.title: Main Function
mainFunction.desc: To enable covers/hatches that "need to be pulled down and retracted" to close automatically, while providing a controlled retraction speed. Typical applications include:
scenarios: Automatic retraction of hoods and hatches

rows.label: Applicability
rows.double: Stable force, high safety guidance requirements

doubleTube.title: Double Tube Structure
items: Preferred for high safety requirement applications

endFitting.title: End Fitting Configuration
items: Threaded Ends: Single/Double end M8 or M10 threads
Ball Joint Ends: √ò10 mm ball joint
Safety Accessories: Must be equipped with "anti-detachment pin" or safety wire

principle.title: 4. Working Principle - Two Modes of Operation

modeA.title: Mode A: Traction Gas Spring (With Pull Force)
flow: Opening Phase: Cover's gravity overcomes initial pull force, pulling the rod out ‚Üí Cover descends
Closing Phase: Gas spring automatically retracts, assisting the cover to pull back up
modeA.scenario: Where the cover's natural descent is sufficient to pull the spring

modeB.title: Mode B: Pure Damper (Damping Only, No Pull Force)
flow: Opening Phase: Manual push throughout, no assistance
Closing Phase: Provides one-way damping only, allowing the cover to descend slowly
modeB.scenario: Light covers or safety-critical scenarios requiring "no assistance + slow descent"

illustration.title: Working Principle Illustration
points: Basic Principle: High-pressure nitrogen gas within the sealed cylinder generates a reverse thrust when the piston rod is pulled. When the external force is released, the gas pressure pushes the piston rod to retract, achieving the automatic closing function.
Key Advantage: Compared to traditional springs, gas springs offer a more stable force curve and longer service life (typically over 100,000 cycles).

formula.title: 5. Quick Selection Formula

closedLength.title: Closed Length Calculation
lines: Where: L = Closed Length (mm) | S = Working Stroke (mm)

selection.title: Selection Steps
steps: Determine Working Stroke S: Based on the required opening range of the cover/hatch
Select Structure Type: Choose Single or Double Tube based on space and force stability requirements
Calculate Closed Length: Use the formula above to determine the minimum closed length
Determine Force: Select appropriate force based on cover weight and pull resistance
Confirm End Fitting: Choose threaded or ball joint, and configure anti-detachment pin

formula.tip: If unsure about specific parameters, we recommend starting with common stock items (150 N / 200 mm Stroke / Single Tube) for quick sample verification.

items.q: ‚ë† Can the initial pull force be reduced below 80 N?
items.a: Answer: It can be reduced to 60 N, but this requires lowering the nitrogen pressure, which will reduce the service life by 20%. We recommend starting at 100 N. This is because excessively low initial pressure increases the gas expansion coefficient, affecting long-term stability.

items.q: ‚ë° The force progression in the single tube is too high, can it be improved?
items.a: Answer: Switch to a Double Tube structure for a flatter force curve, at an approx. 30% increase in cost. The double tube design reduces the force progression rate from 100 N ‚Üí 170-180 N to 100 N ‚Üí ~150 N by diverting damping.

items.q: ‚ë¢ What is the fastest lead time?
items.a: Answer: Conventional 150/250 N, 150/200 mm stroke single tube blanks are stocked (500 units), shipping within 72 hours; non-standard items take 10 days. We maintain inventory on common specifications to ensure rapid response.

Answer: Default certifications include RoHS and 48h Salt Spray Test; military-grade products require additional MIL-STD-810G vibration testing, adding 7 days to the cycle. All products comply with the EU RoHS directive and can be exported directly to European and American markets.

items.q: ‚ë§ I want to conceal the anti-detachment pin on the end fitting?
items.a: Answer: We offer an "internal thread + safety wire" solution, which maintains the external appearance of a standard ball joint. This ensures both safety and an improved product aesthetic.

hero.title: Compression Gas Spring
hero.subtitle: Compression Gas Spring (Gas Strut) - Technical Guide

content.title: Compression Gas Spring
content.definition: (also known as Gas Strut, Gas Spring, Gas Lift, or Support Rod) is an industrial component that uses high-pressure inert gas (typically nitrogen) to provide controlled support, buffering, and lifting force. It's widely used in applications requiring precise, smooth motion control.

coreFunction.title: Core Function
coreFunction.description: Through compressed nitrogen, gas springs provide stable lifting force to assist in opening, supporting, and cushioning heavy components.

items.name: Furniture:
items.value: Flip-up doors, cabinet doors, height-adjustable tables

items.name: Industrial Machinery:
items.value: Equipment enclosures, maintenance covers, safety guards
Specify the use case and required motion.
Record the extended and compressed center-to-center distances.
Calculate the necessary force based on load and geometry.
Select fittings compatible with your mounting points.

subItems.value: Consider special coatings or stainless steel for corrosion resistance.

hero.title: Micro Gas Spring Solutions
hero.description: Precision-engineered miniature gas springs for compact spaces‚Äîdelivering light thrust, short stroke, and silent operation

definition.title: 1. Product Definition
content: Micro Gas Spring, also known as miniature gas spring, micro gas strut, or small gas spring, is a precision product created by proportionally scaling down standard gas springs.

These compact actuators are engineered for applications where space is at a premium and performance cannot be compromised. Whether supporting inspection hatches in medical devices or enabling smooth operation in handheld tools, micro gas springs deliver reliable, whisper-quiet motion control.
definition.quote: The core value lies in meeting the stringent demands of confined spaces for "light thrust, short stroke, and low noise"‚Äîmaking it an irreplaceable precision micro-actuator where traditional mechanical springs or standard gas springs fall short.

specifications.title: 2. Core Dimensions & Force Values
specifications.description: Micro gas springs feature ultra-compact design with refined force options to accommodate diverse miniaturized equipment requirements.

items.spec: 8 mm / 10 mm
items.remark: 10 mm is the market standard, most widely applied.
Rod diameter determines load capacity and structural strength.
Increments of 5 mm provide flexible selection options.
30 / 50 / 80 / 100 N are standard stock configurations.
Applies to 10‚Äì100 mm stroke range; ideal for weight-sensitive designs.

performance.title: 3. Performance Indicators
performance.description: While maintaining ultra-compact dimensions, micro gas springs are optimized for performance, with particular emphasis on low noise and extended service life.

items.remark: Ensures quiet operation, meeting precision instrument requirements.
Guaranteed leak-free operation under rated load and stroke.
Standard corrosion resistance; 48 h premium option available.
Precise unlock force control for self-locking variants.

connectors.title: 4. End Connector Types
connectors.description: To accommodate diverse installation environments, micro gas springs offer multiple end connector options for rapid, reliable integration.

items.application: High-strength applications, precise alignment, or nut-fixed installations.
Fast assembly, plastic or thin-sheet structures; greatly simplifies installation.

items.spec: √ò6 mm stainless steel ball / POM socket
items.application: Requires 180¬∞ rotation or multi-angle articulation in complex linkages.

applications.title: 5. Typical Applications
applications.description: Leveraging their compact size, lightweight design, and precise thrust characteristics, micro gas springs are extensively deployed in space and weight-sensitive precision equipment.

items.title: Small Inspection Hatches:
items.description: Medical POCT (Point-of-Care Testing) devices, analytical instruments‚Äîproviding lid support and cushioning.

items.title: Handheld Tool Access Doors:
items.description: Electric torque wrenches, precision measurement instruments‚Äîenabling smooth battery cover or service hatch operation.

items.title: Mini Drawer Auto-Eject:
items.description: Cash registers, test fixtures, precision storage cabinets‚Äîdelivering gentle, automatic drawer extension.

items.title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Payload Doors:
items.description: In weight-critical applications, providing reliable hatch actuation while minimizing payload burden.

faq.title: 6. Customer FAQs & Response Templates
faq.description: Below are the most frequently asked questions during selection and quotation, with professional responses to quickly identify customer needs.

items.question: ‚ë† Can you manufacture 8 mm tube diameter?

cta.title: Ready to find your perfect push-to-unlock gas spring?
desc: Our engineering team can assist with selection, customization, and rapid delivery.
Contact us today for a detailed quote or technical consultation.

definition.title: What is a Push-to-Unlock Gas Spring?
definition.description: A Push-to-Unlock Gas Spring is a specialized type of lockable gas spring that remains in a locked state by default. The lock is released by simply pushing the mechanism, allowing for controlled movement. Once the external force is removed, it automatically returns to a secure, locked position. This design is perfect for applications demanding both stability and quick, easy adjustments.

mechanism.title: How It Works: The Locking Mechanism
mechanism.description: Our Push-to-Unlock Gas Springs feature a precision-engineered valve system. In its resting state, the valve is closed, creating a rigid lock. A small, targeted push actuates the valve, opening it and allowing the gas and oil to flow, enabling smooth extension or compression. Releasing the push reseals the valve, instantly re-engaging the lock. This simple yet robust mechanism ensures fail-safe performance and exceptional durability.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
specs.description: Our Push-to-Unlock Gas Springs are available in a wide range of configurations to meet your specific needs. Key specifications include:

items.name: End Fittings
items.value: Variety of standard and custom options

questions.q: What is the primary advantage of a push-to-unlock system?
questions.a: The main benefit is safety and convenience. The spring is always locked, preventing accidental movement. It only releases when intentionally pushed, providing a secure and user-friendly experience.

questions.q: Can the locking force be customized?
questions.a: Yes, we can tailor the locking force, extension speed, and compression resistance to your exact application requirements. Our engineers will work with you to define the perfect performance profile.

questions.q: Is this type of spring suitable for outdoor applications?
questions.a: Absolutely. We offer stainless steel versions with enhanced corrosion resistance, making them ideal for marine, agricultural, and other demanding outdoor environments.

questions.q: What is the typical lifespan of these springs?
questions.a: Our Push-to-Unlock Gas Springs are designed for high-cycle applications, with a typical service life exceeding 50,000 cycles under normal operating conditions.

services.title: Custom Engineering & Support
services.description: We go beyond standard products to provide solutions. Our services include:

hero.title: Lockable Gas Spring
hero.subtitle: Rigid locking or elastic soft-rebound ‚Äî precision positioning you can trust

why.title: What is Adjustable Lockable Gas Spring?
why.subtitle: DKG has a line of adjustable locking gas springs which look like traditional gas springs but can be locked in any position along the stroke. There's an internal locking mechanism that's actuated by a release pin located at the end of the rod. To fit your product requirements, we offer three types of adjustable locking gas springs:

zero.title: Rigid in compression:
zero.desc: No movement when the rod is pushed, but some movement when the rod is pulled.

flexible.title: Rigid in extension:
flexible.desc: No movement when the rod is pulled, but some movement when the rod is pushed.

highLoad.title: High Load Capacity
highLoad.desc: Withstand lateral forces ‚â• 2,000 N with reliable locking force plateau performance.

technology.title: Rigid vs. Elastic: The Core Difference

rigid.title: Rigid Locking
points: Dual Chamber ‚Äì Oil-gas separation with floating piston
High Locking Force ‚Äì ‚â• 2,000 N lateral capacity
Best For ‚Äì Operating tables, tooling fixtures, aircraft bins

elastic.title: Elastic Locking
points: Soft Rebound ‚Äì Allows ‚â§ 5 mm elastic displacement
Single Chamber ‚Äì N‚ÇÇ + lubricating oil mixture
Cushioning Effect ‚Äì Gentle positioning with damping
Best For ‚Äì Wheelchairs, hospital beds, office furniture

forcePerformance.title: Locking Force Performance
forcePerformance.desc: The locking force curve shows the stability plateau‚Äîthe higher and flatter the plateau, the more reliable the locking performance.
forcePerformance.safetyText: Always ensure: Plateau Force ‚â• Customer's Maximum Lateral Load √ó 1.5 Safety Factor

rigid.desc: Rigid Locking: S = working stroke, L = extended length (mm)

elastic.desc: Elastic Locking: S = working stroke, L = extended length (mm)

manufacturing.title: Precision Manufacturing Process
manufacturing.desc: Every lockable gas spring undergoes rigorous quality control with specialized precision assembly steps.

difference.title: Key Difference
difference.desc: Compared to standard gas springs, lockable versions include a critical precision assembly step for the floating piston, needle valve, and steel ball locking mechanism.

qa.title: Quality Assurance
qa.desc: Force characteristic testing, pressure retention verification, and 10,000-cycle leakage testing ensure long-term reliability and performance.

items.title: Long Lead Times
items.desc: We reduce delivery from 8‚Äì12 weeks to 2‚Äì4 weeks as a direct replacement for Stabilus, Suspa, and Hahn products.

items.title: Micro-Movement After Locking
items.desc: Switch to our Rigid Series (KQ10-28 Rigid) for zero-displacement performance.

items.title: Release Mechanism Mismatch
items.desc: We offer full customization for ‚â§ √ò8 mm side pins or top buttons to fit your existing structure.

items.title: Missing Technical Drawings
items.desc: We provide sample measurement + CAD + 3D PDF within 48 hours.

items.title: Incomplete Certifications
items.desc: We deliver TS16949, ISO9001, RoHS, 96-hour salt spray, and SGS reports‚Äîall in one package.

items.question: What makes marine gas springs different from standard gas springs?
items.answer: Marine gas springs use 316L stainless steel construction and specialized seals to resist corrosion from salt water and harsh marine environments. They're also designed to meet Z√∂lle erledigt for marine applications.

items.question: How do I calculate the force needed for my marine application?
items.answer: Force calculation depends on the weight of the hatch/cover, mounting geometry, and desired opening effort. Our engineers provide free consultation to determine the optimal force for your specific application.

items.question: What's the typical lifespan of marine gas springs?
items.answer: Our marine gas springs are designed for 100,000+ cycles and typically last 10-15 years in normal marine use. We offer a 30-year warranty on materials and workmanship.

items.question: Can you provide custom mounting brackets?
items.answer: Yes, we offer custom mounting brackets and hardware designed specifically for marine applications. All brackets are made from marine-grade materials with proper corrosion protection.

items.question: What certifications do your marine gas springs have?
items.answer: Our marine gas springs meet ABYC standards and are ISO 9001:2015 certified. We also provide CE marking for international compliance when needed.

whatIsGS.title: What is a gas spring?
description: **Gas springs** are hydro-pneumatic energy storage components. They consist of a precision piston rod moving within a sealed cylinder filled with pressurized nitrogen and oil.
No matter the position of the gas spring, the pressure around the piston is consistently uniform, due to the rod‚Äôs small cross-sectional area.This why gas spring perform steady than coil spring.

The spring force **(F)** is calculated as the pressure differential **(ŒîP)** between the internal and external environments acting on the piston rod cross-sectional area **(A): ( F = ŒîP / times A)**.
Specifications can be tailored by adjusting nitrogen injected, oil quantity, and piston rod area to meet specific application requirements.
In high-pressure environments, the pressure difference **ŒîP** must be carefully managed.
Following introduce different types of gas spring.

howGSWork.title: How Gas Springs Work?
desc: Gas springs‚Äîalso known as gas struts or gas dampers‚Äîwork by using compressed nitrogen gas as an elastic energy storage material within a sealed metal cylinder. The cylinder also contains a small amount of hydraulic oil (such as lubricating or damping oil). These oils serve three main functions:
Support the gas sealed within the cylinder.
Lubricate moving parts to reduce wear.
Provide damping.

When you push the piston rod into the cylinder (this is the **compression** process), the space available for the nitrogen gas gets smaller. Just like squeezing a balloon makes the pressure inside go up, this smaller volume causes the gas pressure inside the cylinder to rise‚Äîthis follows [Boyle‚Äôs Law](https://www.britannica.com/science/Boyles-law).

The force the gas spring puts out gets stronger as you push the rod in, and it‚Äôs strongest when the rod is fully pressed into the cylinder. This more steady, reliable force than coil spring, is why gas springs are used in everyday things like car tailgates (to hold them open gently), industrial machines (to control movement), and ergonomic furniture (like adjustable office chairs).

KeyBehavior.title: Gas Spring Force Curve
desc: If you look at the diagram above, you‚Äôll see how the gas spring acts as the piston moves.

With gas springs, force increases exponentially as they are compressed, requiring less initial force to compress them. As the gas spring nears the end of its stroke, the compression force needed rises.
** Piston Extended State **
When the piston is fully extended, the cylinder has the most space for gas.
** Piston Compressed State **

As the piston moves to fully compressed, the gas space shrinks‚Äîso the pressure goes up (you can see this on the solid line in the diagram). The dashed line shows how the cylinder volume decreases at the same time.
imageCaption: **F1** = extension force with extended piston rod.
**F2** = extension force with compressed piston rod.
**F3** = pull-in force with extended piston rod.
**F4** = pull-in force with compressed piston rod.

CriticalPerformanceMeasure.title: A Critical Performance Measure: The K-Factor
frontdesc: The extension force is calculated by multiplying the filling pressure by the piston rod‚Äôs cross-sectional area. Size as well as force can be made according to your requirements.
DK standard gas springs offer extension forces from **10 N to 5000N,**  with tolerance is ¬± 5-7%.
The specified force (F‚ÇÅ) is always measured at **20¬∞C ¬± 2¬∞C**, with the piston rod facing downward.
Physically, the actual force of a gas spring depends on the temperature. For each 10¬∞C, the force changes by approx 3,3%.
desc: To define how well a gas spring works, engineers use something called the K-factor (or **gas spring progression rate**). Put simply, this is the percentage change in force between two states:
Unloaded: When the piston is at P1 (fully extended, the spring‚Äôs **starting position**).
Fully loaded: When the piston is at P2 (fully compressed).

Good quality gas springs have a very low K-factor‚Äîusually between 1.05 and 1.8. For comparison, mechanical compression springs (like the coil ones we mentioned earlier) have much higher K-factors. A low K-factor means the spring‚Äôs force stays steady as it compresses‚Äîthis is important for applications where you need consistent lifting or damping (like holding a heavy car tailgate at any angle).

One quick note for calculations: Gas springs are pre-charged to a specific force at P1 (we call this force F1)‚Äîso you should always use F1 as your starting point when figuring out the right gas spring for a job.

Replacement.title: How to Choose a Gas Spring: Replacement by Code and Size?
Replacement.subTitle: Replacement, according to code and size(key: EL2 / stroke / pressure)
desc: **Stroke of a Gas Spring:** This indicates the maximum range of motion of the rod, ranging from its fully retracted point to its fully extended point.
**EL1: Extended or Expanded Length:** This term denotes the total length of the gas spring, measured from the midpoint of one end fitting to the midpoint of the opposite end fitting.
**EL2:** If no end fittings are specified, it pertains to the length from the rod end to the tube end.

howChooseGS.title: How to Choose a Gas Spring: A Simple Guide for Engineers
howChooseGS.description: You, as an engineer, have a certain problem which has to do with controlled movement and needs to be solved without extra engergy? Follow questions to get your selection done.We can assist you in selecting the proper gas spring for your application‚Äîand also can help with the design!
howChooseGS.imageNote: Note: We will receive your input and get back to you within **12hours**.

howItWork.title: Here‚Äôs how it works:
list: 1. **Simple Sketch** ‚Äì Provide a basic drawing (like the example on the top) showing:
The weight of the moving part
All dimensions (measured from the pivot/hinge point)
2. **We Handle the Rest!** ‚Äì Send us your sketch, and we‚Äôll recommend the best gas spring for your needs.
It‚Äôs that easy! **Just share your requirements**, and we‚Äôll take care of the rest.

table: Determination of minimum extension force F1
L=Distance between the center of gravity to the Center of gyration(Unit:mm)
b=Effective force arm when the gas spring extends(Unit:mm)
P=Mounting position on the gas spring door, namely about 1/3L away from the center of gyration.

EFC.title: Extension Force Calculation
desc: The extension force is calculated by multiplying the filling pressure by the piston rod‚Äôs cross-sectional area. By adjusting these factors, DK can produce gas springs with a wide range of extension forces to meet your needs.

These values can be influenced, e.g.by the gas volume or the oil quantity. A special characteristic of DK gas springs is the low friction figure.Through the combinations of different nozzle orifices and oil quantity, its possible to control the push-out and pushin speed as required.

GSInstallationGuide.title: Gas spring : Selection of Installation Location
desc: 1. The piston rod **must be installed in a downward orientation** (never inverted). This minimizes friction and ensures optimal damping and cushioning performance.

2. Correct fulcrum positioning is critical: When the associated component (e.g., a door) is closed, the gas spring‚Äôs movement must pass beyond the structural centerline. This prevents unintended automatic resetting (e.g., the spring pushing the component open).
3. Adjust joint orientation by rotating the cylinder or piston rod clockwise.
4. Ensure proper dimensions and force rating. For example, in hood applications, the piston rod should retain ~10 mm of stroke when closed.
5. Operate within the ambient temperature range: -30‚ÑÉ to +80‚ÑÉ.
6. Gas springs are high-pressure components‚Äî**never disassemble, heat, bake, or strike them**.
7. Avoid tilting/lateral forces during operation; do not use as handrails.
swinging. Misalignment may cause jamming or noise.
8. To protect seals and extend lifespan:
Avoid damaging the piston rod surface.
Do not apply paint/chemicals to the piston rod.
Do not pre-install the spring before welding, grinding, or painting.
